tagline: V.D.Jhangan vs State Of Uttar Pradesh on 3 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: state of uttar pradesh was trying for offences under s. 161 of the indian penal code and s. 5 ( 2 ) read with s. 4 ( 1 ) of the india penal code. the appellant, an employee of the ministry of commerce, was tried for offences. he was convicted and his appeal before the high court failed.

tagline: State Of Madras vs A.R. Srinivasan on 2 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: srinivasan's case was heard in the early hours of the day. the state of madras was the first to respond to the case. the case is expected to be heard at the end of the year. the indian government is now trying to find a solution to the problem.

tagline: Arnold Rodricks & Anr vs State Of Maharashtra & Ors on 14 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: the office of commissioner was abolished in 1950 but it was revived in 1958. section 3 ( 4 ) of the act gave the state government power to confer and impose on the commissioner powers and duties under any other enactments for the purpose of conferring powers on commissioners thereunder. the schedule to the act amended various enactments to amend or delete any entry in the schedule.

tagline: K. P. Chowdhary vs State Of Madhya Pradesh & Ors on 15 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: madhya pradesh land revenue code, s. 155 ( b ) recovery under implied contract. appellant gave the highest bids for two forest contracts at an auction. the appellant signed the contract form as required, and the documents were seat to the chief conservator of forests.

tagline: Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd vs M. W. Pradhan on 21 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: indian companies act, 1956, ss. 439 ( 1 ) and 434 - whether receiver appointed by court is a'creditor'within the meaning of s. 434. the appellant company purchased a farm from a joint hindu family for rs. 40 lacs out of which rs. 25 lacs remained to be paid.

tagline: Gopalakrishna Pillai And Others vs Meenakshi Ayal And Others on 31 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: bachawat, r. s. sarkar, a. k. ( cj ) mudholkar, j. m. and others date of judgment. the bench held the will was not genuine and its execution was valid. but in a letters patent appeal, the bench upheld the will and directed the question whether the respondents were the next reversioners of n should be tried afresh.

tagline: State Of Nagaland vs Ratan Singh, Etc on 9 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: the high court issued a writ directing the state not to proceed with the trial under the rules of 1937. the district of nagaland and the district were both granted the power to make or propose laws and the governor - general was allowed to legislate separately for the backward tract. the area where the trial was taking place was one of the backward sections.

tagline: Dolai Molliko & Ors vs Krushna Chandra Patnaik & Ors on 23 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: application was made for bringing on record heirs and heirs. but when respondent's further appeal was pending in the high court. the case is expected to be heard later this month in a bid to bring on record's heirs and the heirs of the deceased had been brought on record.

tagline: Badku Joti Savant vs State Of Mysore on 1 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: the appellant was found in possession of. contraband gold. he was prosecuted under s. 167 ( 81 ) of the land customs act ( 9 of 1924 ) the high court of mysore, in appeal against the acquittal, considered the evidence and relying on the. judge's decision to acquit him.

tagline: State Of Uttar Pradesh vs Akbar Ali Khan on 9 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: the respondent was selected for permanent promotion to the post of district of uttar pradesh. he was placed on probation for a period of two years. on april 29, 1953, he was told that his probation was terminated and he was transferred to post of naib districtdar.

tagline: Gordon Woodroffe & Co vs Sheikh M. A. Majid & Co on 22 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: the appellant was buying the goods for resale in u. k. the price quoted was c. i. f. less 2 1 / 2 %. the contract between sale and agency to sell - account stated, what is - when can be re - opened. the trial judge dismissed the suit, saying that an account should be taken of the company's dealings.

tagline: Kulathil Mammu vs The State Of Kerala on 2 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: a writ petition was filed in the high court in kerala. he had'migrated'to pakistan within the meaning of art. 7 - migrated'means of - whether mere movement from one place to another constitutes migration. in its wider sense, the word " migrated " is capable of two meanings.

tagline: Addl. Collector Of Customs, ... vs M/S. Best & Co on 25 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: the appellants immediately applied for certified copies of the judgment and order. they filed an application for leave to appeal against the order of the high court. the court dismissed the application on the ground that it was barred by time taken for obtaining the certified copy of the judgement or order.

tagline: Narandas Morardas Gaziwala & Ors vs S. P. Am. Papammal & Anr on 25 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: indian evidence act, 1872, s. 92, proviso 3 - oral agreement not to enforce promissory note. the agent pleaded an oral agreement by which the principals were not allowed to enforce. the parole agreement could not be proved in view of agent's case.

tagline: Ghanshiam Das vs Devi Prasad & Another on 11 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: appellants filed a suit against appellant claiming rent for the period october 1, 1952 to september 30 1953. the court ruled that the land in question stood vested in the state of u. p. with effect from july 1 1952 and no rent was payable to the respondents. the suit was partly decreed by the first appellate court.

tagline: M. Padmanabha Setty vs K. P. Papiah Setty on 11 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: application under s. 8 ( 3 ) of the mysore house rent and accommodation control act, 1951, for eviction of the appellant on the ground that the respondent needed the premises for the purpose of shifting his business which he was carrying on in a rented building. the high court in revision set aside the appellate order and restored the order of eviction.

tagline: Mrs. Veeda Menezes vs Yusuf Khan And Anr on 31 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: high court found offending act came within general exception of s. 323 of the indian penal code as it was trivial. section 95 applies only when the act causes harm or is known to be likely to cause harm. in appeal to this court, the appellant found that the act was trivial and that word has in many other sections.

tagline: Dhanji Ram Sharma vs Superintendent Of Police, North ... on 17 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: judgment r. s. bachawat, j. 1, directed the entry of his name in part ii of the surveillance register. the history sheet and the register are kept under the punjab police rules, 1934 framed under the indian police act, 1861. the appellant filed a writ petition challenging the legality of these and other actions of the respondents.

tagline: M/S. Nandram Hunatram, Calcutta vs Union Of India & Anr on 29 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: state government gave a notice asking the firm to remedy the defect within sixty days failing which it would take over the colliery. state government stepped in and made a promise to the essential workmen that their wages would be paid. the firm filed a revision before the central government rejected the revision. the state government refused to give a hearing to the firm and said it did not give any reasons.

tagline: Ellerman & Bucknall Steamship Co. ... vs Sha Misrimal Bherajee on 29 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: the respondent entered into two contracts with the b company ( sellers ) of new york to purchase certain chemicals and in pursuance of contracts placed three indents for the material in 1951 and 1951. the sellers then negotiated the bills of lading against the letters of credit and obtained payment of the contract price. when the shipment arrived in india it discovered that the drums contained only coal dust and not the chemicals ordered.

tagline: M/S. Om Oil & Oilseeds Exchange ... vs Their Workmen on 28 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: appellant justified its action on the ground that appellant had recorded valid reasons for departure from the rule. appellant's action in retrenching some of its employees was mala fide, as the appellant did not follow the " first come. last go " rule.

tagline: Ram Kishore vs State Of U.P on 28 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: in 1960, appellant was found in possession of labels and tins carrying marks deceptively similar to the complainants'trade mark. in november 1960, the appellant found in. possession of. labels and tobacco tins. carrying marks similar to. the complainant's pleasants had acquiesced that he was infringing their trade - mark but no further action was taken.

tagline: M/S. Ram Chand And Sons Sugar Mills ... vs Kanhaya Lal Bhargava & Ors on 10 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: court acting under o. xxix r. 3 of the code of civil procedure directed j one of the directors of the company to answer material questions in relation to the suit. the high court dismissed the appellant's revision petition and appealed to this court by special leave. it was contended on behalf of appellant that inherent power could not be invoked in the case.

tagline: Cochin Devaswom Board, Trichur vs Vamana Shetty And Ors on 2 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: goa devaswom board claimed to recover michavaram from the kanam tenants at the rates settled under the notice of 1910. the board claimed the board was not to enforce the notices. the diwan published rules in 1910 regulating the procedure in the matter of collection paattam, michavaris, renewal fee and other dues payable.

tagline: Nathia Agarwalla & Another vs Musst. Jahanara Begum & Others on 15 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: the execution proceedings began in 1954 and were pending when the assam non - agricultural urban areas tenancy act 1955 came into force from june 26, 1955. a decree for ejectment was passed against the appellants in november 1950 in a suit filed against them by the respondents and was later confirmed by the high court.

tagline: State Of Maharashtra vs Narharrao on 14 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: narharrao date of judgment in maharashtra, india, was convicted of accepting a bribe for weakening a prosecution case. he was charged under s. 161, indian penal code, and s. 5 ( 1 ) ( b ) and ( 2 ) of the prevention of corruption act. the high court allowed the appeal on the ground that of the prosecution was barred after the date of alleged offence.

tagline: Sunder Singh And Ors vs Narain Singh And Ors on 11 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: appellants purchased certain lands in the state of punjab and the respondents filed a suit claiming a right of preemption thereon. under a scheme of consolidation, however, the appellant's right of the land was given to the vendees in lieu of the lands purchased by them, and they contended that the right was not extend to these lands.

tagline: Dalchand & Ors vs Delhi Imrovement Trust (Now Delhi ... on 24 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: high court refused to decree the suit against the high court. high court was right in refusing to approve the suit. the application was approved by the supreme court. it is the latest in a series of high court hearings in the indian supreme court and the justice of the court.

tagline: State Of West Bengal vs Motilal Kanoria on 15 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: the state of west bengal vs. respondent faced trial for an offence under s. 5 of the imports and exports act 1947. in 1955 the imports ( control ) order no. 17 of 1955 was passed. under cl. 5 ( 4 ) every licencee was enjoined to observe the condition of the licences issued by him.

tagline: Indian Iron & Steel Co. Ltd vs Biswanath Sonar on 22 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: the appellant company gave on lease a piece of land to the respondent in 1938. on june 28, 1950 the company gave notice to respondent terminating the tenancy. the company filed a suit for eviction of the respondingent. but the high court upheld the order and dismissed the suit. the court ruled that the act was from month to month s. 9.

tagline: Himatrao vs Jaikishandas And Ors on 4 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: appellant's suit for partition of his share of'home - farm'land in berar area of madhya pradesh was partly decreed by the trial court. both sides filed appeals and first appellate court decided in favour of the appellant. but the high court dismissed the suit as infructuous on the ground that by virtue of the madhya pradesh abolition of proprietary rights ( estate, mahals ) act.

tagline: Thirunagar Panchayat vs Madurai Co-Operative House ... on 31 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: the respondent - society formed a housing colony, laid out public roads and set apart public common places for the benefit of the members of the colony. the appellant, thereupon, filed a suit for an injunction restraining the response from obstructing the. appellant under s. 58 of the act.

tagline: Charan Singh And Ors vs Babulal And Ors on 25 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: a revision petition to the high court filed by the appellants was dismissed. it was contended that s. 39 of the arbitration act provides for appeals does not apply to arbitrations under s. 37 of the u. p. act. the decision of the civil judge modifying, the award was appealable under. s. 63 of the. arbitration act.

tagline: Firm Bansidhar Premsukhdas vs State Of Rajasthan on 29 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: the appellant filed a suit for the recovery of the excess amount of customs duty paid on the basis that there was a valid contractual liability to grant the concession. in 1951, the respondent revoked the concession and revoked its concession. it was dismissed by the high court on appeal.

tagline: Gyasi Ram vs Brij Bhushan Das And Ors on 30 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: a preliminary decree was passed in the appellant's suit for redemption of a mortgage. it specified the amounts due as principal and interest, provided for payment of interest at 3 % from the date of realisation. appellant appealed against the preliminary decree to the high court and applied for a final decree in his favour.

tagline: The State Of Mysore vs Shanta Veerappa Channa ... on 4 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: the respondent was assessed to sales tax and was served with a notice requiring him to pay the amount within 21 days. he preferred an appeal against the order of assessment but did not pay the tax, nor did he obtain an order of stay of proceedings from teh appellate authority. under the proviso to s. 13 ( 3 ), the assessee has been afforded interim protection from action under s. 12 ( 5 ) and provided he obtains from the appropriate appellate or revisional authority.

tagline: Biswambar Roy vs Girindra Kumar Paul on 30 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: assam act 12 of 1955 was brought into force by a tenant of land in the term of silchar in assam. the tenant claimed protection from eviction under s. 5 ( 1 ) of the act the right of a permanent tenant since he had built within the pres - cribed period structures for residential or business purposes.

tagline: Bhrigunandan Prasad And Ors vs The Appellate Officer & Ors on 25 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: the appellants were mortgagees of. properties including a house on the basis of a mortgage bond executed in 1928. the interest provided in the bond was 9 % per cent per annum compoundable annually. in 1937, the app.ellants filed a suit against the original mortgagors and others including b for the, amount due under the mortgage.

tagline: Kuchiyan Govinda Swami vs Kalliani Amma Lekshmi Amma And Ors on 31 March, 1966
summarized_judgment: the appellant's right to possess and enjoy the property for 12 years in kuzhikanam right with liberty to plant coconut trees thereon. in appeal, the court and high court ruled that appellant was entitled to the right to have the fruit bearing trees. the deed did not grant the right right to use the land on receipt of a certain amount and he agreed compensation for coconut trees.

tagline: The State Of Madras vs M/S. Radio And Electricals Ltd. ... on 19 April, 1966
summarized_judgment: the assessees were registered dealers under the central sales tax act, 1956. they claimed they were liable to pay tax at the concessional rate of tax on the turnover under sec. 8 ( 1 ) of the act. the act and the rules do not impose an obligation upon the dealer to declare that goods purchased by him are intended to be used for sale.

tagline: Uttar Pradesh Co-Operative ... vs M/S Sunder Brothers Of Delhi on 20 April, 1966
summarized_judgment: the appellant society carried on business as public carriers on the kanpur - delhi route. by an agreement in 1954 they appointed the respondents as their managing agents for a period of 3 years. they filed a suit against the society asking for a declaration that the termination of the agreement by the society was illegal and for a mandatory injunction.

tagline: State Of Punjab vs Major Singh on 28 April, 1966
summarized_judgment: act must fall within mischief of the section and would constitute an offence under the section. victim's modesty is the attribute of her sex, according to the common notions of mankind. in the present case there could be no question of the accused having intended to outrage modesty of a woman.

tagline: Veruareddi Ramaraghava Reddy And ... vs Konduru Seshu Reddy And 2 Ors on 26 April, 1966
summarized_judgment: the appellants filed an original petition in the district court under s. 84 ( 2 ) of the madras hindu religious endowments act. 1927 act was repealed by the hindu religious and charles ble awards act of 1951. temple - suit, however, is barred by provisions of s. 42 of the specific relief act, 1877, and ( ii ) compromise decree was invalid.

tagline: Jahuri Sah & Ors vs Dwarka Prasad Jhunjhunwala & Ors on 27 April, 1966
summarized_judgment: the appellants occupied a major portion of the house on an agreed compensation being payable by them to the respondents in respect of the latter's share occupied by them. the app was not incompetent because there was no ouster of the plaintiffs by the respondents. a trial court decided in favour of appellant but high court held against them.

tagline: State Of Bihar vs S. K. Roy on 25 April, 1966
summarized_judgment: the respondent owned a coke plant which belonged to a group of collieries but was later transferred to him. he was prosecuted under para 70 of the coal mines provident fund and bonus schemes act, 1948 ( act 46 of 1948 ) on a complaint that as an owner of a coal mine and an employer within the meaning of the scheme, he did not mine or excavate coal himself nor carry on any operation for obtaining coal.

tagline: State Of Madhya Pradesh vs Shobharam And Ors on 22 April, 1966
summarized_judgment: madhyabharat panchayat act, 1949, was set aside by the high court on the ground that s. 63 of the act, which provides that no legal practi - tioner shall appear on behalf of any party in a proceeding before the trial. the act does not give power to deprive any of his liberty.

tagline: T.D.Gopalan vs Commissioner Of Hindu Religious & ... on 5 April, 1966
summarized_judgment: the appellant sought a declaration that certain premises belonged to his family as private property and did not constitute a temple within meaning of the madras act 19 of 1951. the high court ruled that the property in question was a temple. the application on the ground, inter alia, that the subject matter had to be ascertained with reference to the claim made by the plaintiff in his plaint.

tagline: Commissioner Of Wealth Tax West ... vs Imperial Tobacco Co. Of India Ltd on 15 April, 1966
summarized_judgment: orders of reassessment under s. 16 ( 3 ) read with s. 17 ( b ) of the income tax act. the order was passed by the wealth tax officer in respect of two assessment years, and by those orders, amounts which had been formerly allowed as deduction were included in the total wealth of the respondent.

tagline: Chief Conservator Of Forests And ... vs Rattan Singh on 7 April, 1966
summarized_judgment: act 15 ( 1 ) does not invest the divisional forest officer with authority to determine if the contractor, his servants or his agents have committed a breach of the contract. if a dispute arose between the contractor and forest authorities, there may have to be an assessment, of compensation payable by the contractor to the state.

tagline: Gopi Ram vs State Of Rajasthan & Ors on 19 April, 1966
summarized_judgment: state of rajasthan and ors. shelat & r. dayal judgment is the latest in a series of complaints about the case no longer exists. the case is expected to be heard in the coming days on march 1. it will be the first time a petition has been signed by the government to pass the petition.

tagline: Ram Prasad Dagduram vs Vijay Kumar Motilal Mirakhanwala ... on 18 April, 1966
summarized_judgment: first respondent filed a lawsuit for foreclosure of the mortgage in 1934. it was the daughter's son of mortgagee, claiming to be her adopted son. the high court granted the application under 0. 1, r. 10 ( 1 ) of sub - r. ( 2 ) of 0. 2 ) provided for addition of plaintiffs and could not justify the addition.

tagline: Kalarimadathil Unni vs State Of Kerala on 22 April, 1966
summarized_judgment: appellants were convicted of murder under s. 302 read with s. 34 i. p. c. on the allegation that they had laid their victim in a drain after closing his mouth with cotton wool soaked in chloroform. the first clause of s. 300 says that culpable homicide is murder if the act by which death is caused is done with the intent of causing death.

tagline: Vajesingh Salambhai Naik & Ors vs State Of Gujarat & Anr on 1 April, 1966
summarized_judgment: appellants had applied for restoration of appeals within 30 days of receipt of orders of dismissal of the appeals. appellant's applications under art. 227 of the constitution to the high court failed and they came by way of special leave, to this court. application was dismissed for non - prosecution, but it was obligatory on its part of deciding the appeals on merits.

tagline: Vithal Das vs Rupchand & Ors on 7 April, 1966
summarized_judgment: the plaintiffs filed a suit for partition of immovable property constituting two blocks and for rendition of accounts. they claimed that the property was purchased with the capital of the partnership firm in which the plaintiffs and the defendant were partners. the high court granted the plaintiffs a decree for most of the reliefs sought.

tagline: Patel Rambhai Bacharbhai & Anr vs Patel Dahyabhai Becharbhai & Anr on 4 April, 1966
summarized_judgment: the second respondent sold his lands to the appellants who were put in possession in 1934. the first respondent was impleaded as a party to the petition in 1947. in 1947, the board reversed the board's order and remanded the case to the civil judge.

tagline: P. L. Lakhanpal vs Union Of India on 19 April, 1966
summarized_judgment: petitioner was detained under r. 30 ( 1 ) ( b ) of the constitution for a writ of habeas corpus challenging the legality of the detention order on various grounds. petitioner, editor of a newspaper, has filed a petition under art. 32 of india's constitutions challenging the court's legality.

tagline: War Profits Tax Commissioner, ... vs M/S. Rinodram Balchand Of Ujjain on 20 April, 1966
summarized_judgment: war profits tax officer included the amount in the assessee's taxable income. in 1946, an explanation was added after r. 3 of the first schedule to the ordinance of 1944. in 1947, another amendment or dinance was promulgated in an explanation. the order was upheld by the appellate assistant commissioner and the commissioner.

tagline: The Barium Chemicals Ltd. And Anr vs The Company Law Board And Others on 4 May, 1966
summarized_judgment: the company law board was constituted under section 10e of the companies act, 1956, and the central government delegated some of its powers under section 642. the government also framed rules under section 237, to the board. in february, 1954, under the power vested in him by rule 3 the law board. under the act, the business of ordering investigations under section 800 and 237 was allotted to board.

tagline: State Of Jammu And Kashmir vs Bakshi Ghulam Mohammad on 6 May, 1966
summarized_judgment: the first respondent became a member of the council of ministers of the state of jammu and kashmir in 1947. in 1965 he filed a writ petition and quashed the proceedings of the committee of inquiry. the state appealed to the high court, allowing the court to quash the proceedings.

tagline: H. B. Yeshwant Rao Ghorpade vs The Commissioner Of Wealth Tax, ... on 6 May, 1966
summarized_judgment: in 1957 appellant created two trusts by two sepa - rate deeds, one of which was a charitable trust and the other a family trust. he transferred certain shares to the family trust the scheme of which they were to remain. clause 21 to 25 trustees could expend the income accruing under the settlement to each of the beneficiaries therein for the maintenance, education, health, marriage and. advancement of the trust.

tagline: Nanikant Ambalal Mody vs Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... on 4 May, 1966
summarized_judgment: appellant's advocate maintained his accounts on the cash system gave up practice when he was elevated to the bench in 1957. the appellant then went in revision to the commissioner of income - tax contending that the said receipts were not income and had been wrongly taxed. if the income is so included, it falls outside s. 12.

tagline: Ramchandra Aggarwal And Anr vs State Of Uttar Pradesh & Anr on 5 May, 1966
summarized_judgment: code of civil procedure ( act 5 of 1898 ), s. 146 ( 1 ) refers to a persona designata. it was contended that the district judge acted without jurisdiction because ( i ) the provisions of c. p. c. did not apply to the proceeding as it was not a proceeding in a court of civil jurisdiction within the meaning of s. 141.

tagline: Indian Chemical Products vs State Of Orissa & Anr on 5 May, 1966
summarized_judgment: indian companies act, 1913, s. 38 - court's power under - pro - per exercise of. the state of orissa & anr. in 1955 the state had acquired title to these shares by operation of law. but the directors refused to do so. the high court allowed the application and passed an order directing rectification of the registrar within a fortnight.

tagline: Kuppa Goundan & Anr vs M.S.P. Rajesh on 5 May, 1966
summarized_judgment: appellants gave evidence against appellant for giving false evidence under s. 193 indian penal code, and adduced evidence in sup - port of his contention. appellant's complaint was filed in the court of the magistrate under s'476 ( 1 ) criminal procedure code.

tagline: Abhoy Pada Sara vs Sudhir Kumar Mondal on 5 May, 1966
summarized_judgment: when india declared " sunris excluding sahas " as a schduled caste, it indicates that sunris are a caste distinct from the sunri caste, nor was it intended to exclude from sunris those members of that caste who bore the surname saha. when the respondent challenged the election to the west bengal legislative assembly, of the appellant who described himself as a member of the caste group but failed to prove the allegation.

tagline: Mahant Shri Srinivasa Ramanuj Das vs Surajnarayan Dass & Anr on 6 May, 1966
summarized_judgment: orissa hindu endowments act, 1939 ( orissa 4 of 1939 ) was under s. 49 of the hindu religious endowments. act was approved by the high court. in appeal by high court, high court dismissed the suit, which on appeal was confirmed. the appeal must be dismissed, but the appeal is dismissed.

tagline: Jaichand Lall Sethia vs State Of West Bengal & Ors on 27 July, 1966
summarized_judgment: appellant was detained under r. 30 of the defence of india rules, 1962. he challenged the order of detention by a petition under, art. 226 of the constitution which was dismissed. in appeal, the high court should have asked for an affidavit from the chief minister of the state who passed the order.

tagline: State Of Madhya Pradesh vs Azad Bharat Finance Co. & Anr on 28 July, 1966
summarized_judgment: truck was found to contain contraband opium and h was tried for offences under ss. 9a and 9b of the opium act. h took a truck on hire from the respondent company. he had no knowledge that the truck was being used for transporting the opium. but the high court held that the word'shall'in that section was not mandatory.

tagline: Pampapathy vs State Of Mysore on 28 July, 1966
summarized_judgment: the appellants were released on bail by the high court under s. 426 cr. p. c., pending disposal of their appeal in high court. they were accused of misusing their liberty and committing acts of violence. but the court has made express provision for the cancellation of bail in certain cases.

tagline: Fatehchand Murlidhar And Anr vs Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... on 19 July, 1966
summarized_judgment: the assessee was a partner in a registered firm. in 1949 he entered into a partnership with strangers and a deed of partnership was executed between them. income tax officer has to find whether it is the partner who is assessable or whether the income should be taken into consideration for income tax purposes.

tagline: Jalan Trading Co. (Private Ltd.) vs Mill Mazdoor Union(With ... on 5 August, 1966
summarized_judgment: the industrial court upheld the plea of the workmen and directed the employers subject to the provisions of the bonus act, 1965. the act was promulgated by the president on may 29, 1965 with immediate effect. the workers were entitled to receive bonus, at the minimum rate of 4 % of the salary or wages or rs. 40 whichever was higher.

tagline: Firm Madanlal Roshanlal Mahajan vs Hukumchand Mills Ltd., Indore on 19 August, 1966
summarized_judgment: the respondent filed a suit against the appellant claiming two sums as losses in respect of two items and interest on the same. the arbitrator, powers of - - lump sum award - amendment of issue - interest pendente lite. in appeal, the court cannot review his award and correct any mistake in adjudication.

tagline: Girja Nandini And Ors vs Bijendra Narain Choudhury on 11 August, 1966
summarized_judgment: appellants and the respondent belonged to the same branch of a hindu undivided family. two branches filed in 1923 a joint suit for partition of the family estate impleaded the other two branches as defendants. in 1923 the court passed a preliminary decree in which tile shares of the branches were given four annas each.

tagline: State Of Mysore & Anr vs S. V. Narayanappa on 22 August, 1966
summarized_judgment: state of mysore and anr. v. narayanappa date of judgment. shelat, j. m. rao, k. subba ( cj ) made a writ petition before the high court ruled that he was entitled to have his appointment regularised under aforesaid government order.

tagline: Khub Chand And Ors vs State Of Rajasthan & Ors on 22 August, 1966
summarized_judgment: rajasthan land acquisition act ( 24 of 1953 ), ss. 4 and 5 ( 2 ) - gave of public notice of substance of notification under s. 4 at convenient places in the district of rajasthan. appellants filed objections questioning his jurisdiction and stopped taking part in proceedings. in 1959, they filed a petition under art. 226, challenging validity of the proceedings.

tagline: Basant Singh vs Janki Singh And Ors on 2 August, 1966
summarized_judgment: the high court ruled that the plaint was not admissible in evidence on two grounds, viz., ( i ) the defendant can rely on a state - ment as an admission, though she is not prepared to accept the correctness of the statements as correct and reject the rest. in other suits, this admission cannot be regarded as conclusive and it is open to the party.

tagline: Mst. Ramrati Kuer vs Dwarika Prasad Singh And Ors on 24 August, 1966
summarized_judgment: appellant's mother executed gift deed in favour of appellant claiming she inherited it from her father - in - law. appellant had survived husband, made by donor in a mortgage suit in 1925 to establish her case. but the appellant was concerned, butit would certainly be piece of evidence to be taken into consideration.

tagline: Bakhshish Singh Dhaliwal vs The State Of Punjab on 31 August, 1966
summarized_judgment: the appellant was convicted by the special tribunal of all the ten charges but the high court convicted him only in respect of three charges. he was convicted of all 10 charges but high court was convicted in contempt of the court of all ten charges. an appellant, a contractor, was tried for offenses under s. 420 indian penal code in relation to works done during world war 11.

tagline: P. Arulswami vs The State Of Madras on 29 August, 1966
summarized_judgment: the appellant was charged with an offence under s. 409, indian penal code. it is similar to s. 106 of the madras village parnchayats act ( mad act x of 1960 ) it is not every offence committed by a public servant who requires sanction for prosecution. an offence may be entirely unconnected with the official duties.

tagline: M. P. Shreevastava vs Mrs. Veena on 24 August, 1966
summarized_judgment: the appellant obtained a decree for restitution of conjugal rights against his wife. there was no pending application for execution of the order. the expression " oourt executing the decree " does not mean a " court seized " order that the decree be recorded as satisfied.

tagline: Jiwanlal Achariya vs Rameshwarlal Agarwalla on 26 August, 1966
summarized_judgment: the appellant executed a promissory note in renewal of this loan. it was not a loan within the meaning of s. 4 of the bihar money - lenders act, but was renewal of a loan. the suit was barred by limitation as the part payment was made in february 1954.

tagline: Mrs. Manorama S. Masurekar vs Mrs. Dhanlaxmi G. Shah And Anr on 23 August, 1966
summarized_judgment: landlord served a notice on the tenant demanding the rent. she refused to receive it and filed a suit for eviction under s. 12 ( 3 ) of the act. the tenant was in arrears of rent for more than six months. she was willing to pay the rent until after the expiry of one month. she must be dealt with under its special provisions.

tagline: Faqir Chand vs Harnam Kaur & Anr on 5 August, 1966
summarized_judgment: the appellant and his father constituted a joint family of the father. less than half the money borrowed was for repaying antecedent debts. appellant's suit was to prevent the sale of the mortgaged property in execution of his father for sale. the trial court dismissed the appeal without deciding the question of legal necessity.

tagline: Shivnarayan Kabra vs The State Of Madras on 23 August, 1966
summarized_judgment: appellant was under s. 420 of the indian penal code and s. 21 of the forward contracts ( regulation ) act, 1952 ( 74 of 1952 ). appellant said he carried out transactions in question through members of recognised associations as an agent of the complainant. the appellant held out as a pucca adatiatia made a public advertisement inviting people to enter into forward transactions through him.

tagline: Chandra Mohan vs State Of Uttar Pradesh & Ors on 8 August, 1966
summarized_judgment: constitution of india 1950, arts. 132 and 133 appeal filed against all respondents - leave to appeal against those not granted by high court, but certificate misleading - - grant of special leave by supreme court. high court calls for applications for recruitment of district judges from such " judicial officers "

tagline: Satrughan Isser vs Smt. Subujpari & Others on 4 August, 1966
summarized_judgment: shah, j. c. wanchoo, k. n. bachawat and other coparceners were on the record as her heirs and legal representatives. the high court reversed this decision and granted a decree for possession of a coparcenary property as at the date of the suit.

tagline: Hasan Nurani Malak vs Assistant Charity Commissioner, ... on 22 August, 1966
summarized_judgment: shelat, j. m. rao, k. subba ( cj ) benchmarked for finding a trust not a public trust. registrar did not cause entry of negative finding in register of public trusts - effect on right to file suit under s. 8 to set aside finding repeal of act 30 of 1951 in application to vidharbha area.

tagline: N. S. Shethna vs Vinubhai Harilal Panchal on 25 August, 1966
summarized_judgment: shelat, j. m. rao, k. subba ( cj ) benchmarked for exhibiting films and licence for selling tickets renewable from year to year - contravention of rules in one year. on december 31, 1960 a notice was served on him requiring him to show cause why his licence should not be suspended for two months.

tagline: Nand Kishore vs Ram Kishan & Anr on 25 August, 1966
summarized_judgment: the landlord of the premises in dispute, obtained a decree for ejectment against landlord claiming to be statutory tenant - if maintainable. section 50 was not a bar to the suit, but the interest of sub - tenant was allowed to subsist is s. 18 ( 2 ), for, s. 17 ( 3 ) of the act, which means that a dispute in respect of such a sub - tenancy could be decided by the controller.

tagline: Gaudi Ramamurthy & Ors vs The State Of Andhra Pradesh & Ors on 26 August, 1966
summarized_judgment: the vantari muttah was granted to their predecessor in interest in return for services as vantarlu'or'foot set'in lieu of services and partly for rent - such lands if excluded from estate under regu - lation of 1802. the land was given to its predecessor by the then zamindar for services.

tagline: Chouthi Parsad Gupta vs Union Of India And Ors on 31 August, 1966
summarized_judgment: the sub - divisional officer, military engineering service, was in possession of some movable property of the judgment - debtor. section 145 of the code of civil procedure only applies when a person becomes liable as a surety. the court ordered attachment under 0. xxi, r. 46, to produce the property, and when it was not produced, proceed under s. 145.

tagline: Shew Bux Mohato & Ors vs Ajit Nath Dutta on 24 August, 1966
summarized_judgment: clause 3 of the will directed s to pay maintenance to the testator's mother. clause 4 provides that s could sell any portion of the estate if necessary. clause 5 provides that the executrix of his estate would pay its debts and realize his dues. clause 3 would provide that s. could sell the estate to her for her natural life certain garden lands.

tagline: Swadeshi Cotton Mills Co. Ltd. vs Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... on 20 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: the appellant - company is managed by a firm of managing agents known as jaipuria brothers ltd. under article 135 of the articles of association of. the company the managing agents were entrusted with general management of the affairs of the company. the total remuneration for the managing agent for the relevant accounting year was calculated at rs. 5, 000 per month plus a commission of 10 %.

tagline: Shree Meenakshi Mills Ltd., ... vs Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... on 19 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: the assessee - mill claimed deduction under s. 10 ( 2 ) of the indian income - tax act of expenses incurred by it and costs awarded to government in respect of unsuccessful writ petition and appeals therefrom. the deduction was disallowed by the departmental authorities, and the question was answered against the high court.

tagline: S. Narayanappa & Ors vs Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... on 27 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: in the reference to the high court, the officer had reasonable grounds for thinking that there was non - disclosure of material facts on the part of the appellant. the officer did not file a return of his income under s. 22 of the income - tax act, 1922 but the incometax officer assessed the income for the assessment year 1951 - 52.

tagline: M. L. Sethi vs R. P. Kapur & Anr on 23 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: appellant lodged a report with the police charging the respondent with certain cognizable offences on 10th december 1958. the appellant filed a complaint under s. 190 criminal procedure code - cognizance. appellant applied to the magistrate's court, but the case ended in an order of discharge.

tagline: Gomathinayagam Pillai And Ors vs Pallaniswami Nadar on 2 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: gomathinayagam pillai and ors were owners of a plot of land which they verbally agreed to sell to the respondent on march 5, 1959. on that date, as against the total agreed price of rs. 15, 106 the responders paid rs. 1006 as an advance amount for which a receipt was executed by the two appellants.

tagline: Union Of India vs Bungo Steel Furniture Pvt. Ltd on 14 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: the arbitrator committed an error : ( i ) with respect to the deduction of an amount, and ( ii ) by granting interest from the date of award till the date when the court passed a decree in terms of the award. the court has no jurisdiction to investigate into the merits of the case and to examine the case.

tagline: State Of Gujarat vs M/S. Raipur Manufacturing ... on 30 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: m / s. raipur manufacturing company was carrying on the business of manufacturing and selling cotton textiles. in the case of coal it was a commodity which the company required for its business and which had been purchased for use in that business. the high court, on a reference, held in favour of the company,. but there was no evidence as to what was the total quantity of coal sold.

tagline: Hukumchand Mills Ltd vs Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... on 22 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: the appellate tribunal has got power to entertain the argument of the department, to remand, and to give the directions to the income - tax officer. under s. 5a ( 8 ) of the act, the tribunal allowed the contenation to be raised and remanded the matter to the officer for considering the question whether the industrial tax rules related to tax on tax on profits of business.

tagline: Rambaran Prosad vs Ram Mohit Hazra & Ors on 6 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: the properties were divided into four blocks a, b, c and d. blocks a and c went to t, and b and d to k. the matter was referred to arbitration. under the award, the properties had agreed that'any party shall have the right of preemption between each other '

tagline: Subhas Chandra Das Mushib vs Ganga Prosad Das Mushib And Ors on 14 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: indian contract act, s. 16 - undue influence - burden of proof - necessity of plea being clearly raised in pleadings. high court tried to make presumption that the donee had influence over donor's father and the plantiff's brothers son in favour of plantiff son in respect of certain properties.

tagline: Bungo Steel Furniture Pvt. Ltd vs Union Of India on 30 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: the union of india entered into two contracts in november 1944 and june 1945 with the appellants for the supply of 4, 700 bins at an agreed price inclusive of the cost of steel. after 2, 172 bins had been manufactured and supplied to the union, the latter cancelled the contract for supply of the balance 2, 528 bins. the arbitrator awarded damages to the company of the amount representing the value of steel used up in making the component parts for bins which had not been assembled into finished bins and were assembled into completed bins by the government.

tagline: Central Bank Of India vs Shri Gokal Chand on 12 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: the appellant was tent filed an application under the delhi rent control act. appellant contended that the respondent did not bona fide need the premises for his own use and prayed for a commission to be issued for the purpose of inspecting the house in which the respondingent was residing. the object of s. 38 ( 1 ) is to give a'right of appeal to a party aggrieved by order which affects his right or liability.

tagline: Meghraj Kothari vs Delimitation Commission & Ors on 20 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: by delimitation commission act, 1962, was published under s. 10 ( 1 ) of the law under art. 329 ( a ) of. the constitution. of india, 1950, arts. 82, 327, 328 and 329 - order under. s. 9 of the act. the petition was rejected - by the high court on the short ground that the notification could not be questioned in any court.

tagline: Raghubans Narain Singh vs The Uttar Pradesh Government ... on 23 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: land acquisition act 1994, 1894, ss. 11, 18, 23 and 28 - compensation. for land acquired - based on an earlier offer to purchase the land - evidence relating to such offer not challenged as not genuine or bona fide - whether proper basis for compensation - should pay interest under s. 28 - if appropriate - court exercising discretion to pay interest.

tagline: Raja Anand Brahma Shah vs State Of Uttar Pradesh And Ors. on 16 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: the declaration shall be published in the official gazette. section 16 relates to the power of the collector to take possession of the land. the collector has made an award under section 11. section : " 16. when the appropriate government directs, the collector... free from all encumbrances "

tagline: Travancore Sugars And Chemicals ... vs Commissioner Of Income-Tax ... on 20 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: appellant claimed the amount so paid to be expenditure allowable under s. 10 ( 2 ) ) the appellant agreed to pay to the government a certain percentage of net profits every year. appellant was formed with a view to taking over certain industrial undertakings from the government of the erstwhile state of travancore. it was urged that the payment formed part of the consideration for the purchase.

tagline: Kuppuswamy Chettiar vs A.S. P. A. Arumugam Chettiar And ... on 6 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: the appellant executed a deed in favour of the respondents, releasing the suit properties, including certain outstanding due from third parties, and, this deed was registered on february 26, 1952. in january 1952, the app applied for a decree setting aside the release deed of february 1952 on the ground that it was vitiated by misrepresentation, fraud and deceit.

tagline: M/S. Guruswamy & Co.Etc vs State Of Mysore & Ors on 26 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: the karnataka health cess act, 1962 provided in s. 3 for the levy and collection of a health. cess at the rate of nine naye paise in the rupee, inter alia, on the items of the state revenue mentioned in schedule a. of schedule a mentioned duty if an excise duty within meaning of entry 51 of list ii of the constitution.

tagline: Shinde Brothers vs Dy. Commissioner Raichur & Ors on 26 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: dy. c. commissioner raichur & ors. hidayatullah & s. m. bachawat & raghubar dayal judgment. the case no longer has a case to be heard in the civil rights movement. some of the cases have come under fire for their handling of the case.

tagline: Tilak Ram And Ors. vs Nathu And Ors. on 5 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: ancestors of the appellants for rs. 1, 290 were owners of lands admeasuring 155 bighas. they executed seven usufructuary mortgages in favour of one dharamdas to secure repayment of an aggregate sum of rs 2, 290 advanced by him.

tagline: State Of Gujarat vs Vinaya Chandra Chhota Lal Patni on 5 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: the complainant was charged under s. 408 i. p. c. for misappropriating the funds of his employer. four documents were found to be handed over to complainant by the respondent. the two documents were the, respondent's statement as are'accused n a criminal case and an application given by the. respondent in another case. the high court acquitted the respondingent holding that. ( i ) it was for the prosecution to prove the disputed handwriting.

tagline: Manujendra Dutt vs Purendu Prosad Roy Chowdhury & Ors on 22 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: calcutta thika tenancy act, 1949, was passed by the west bengal legislature. the appellant was the tenant of the respondents on a piece of land. but the lessee was entitled to renew the lease after that period under certain conditions. the court of wards in wards thereupon filed a suit in court of the first subordinate judge alipore for eviction of the patient.

tagline: State Of Assam vs Ranga Mahammad And Ors on 21 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: the respondent filed petitions under am 226 and 227 in the assam high court asking that notifications by the state government of the transfer of one district & sessions judge and the appointment and posting of another be quashed on the ground that the high court alone could make the transfers and. in any event, high court was to be consulted and was not consulted before the impugned orders were made.

tagline: Jugal Kishore Baldeo Sarai vs Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... on 20 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: karta should be deducted as an item of expenditure under s. 10 ( 2 ) ( xv ) of the income - tax act, 1922. the claim was rejected by the department, the high court and high court. karta was a hindu family carrying on a joint family business. the family consists of two brothers and their minor sons.

tagline: Sri Vedagiri Lakshmi Narasimha ... vs Induru Pattabhirami Reddy on 6 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: trustees of a tempter filed a suit for rendition of accounts'against, the ex - trustees, in respect of their management of the temple. the defendants were not obliged to render accounts in the absence of allegations of acts of negligence or willful default, and that s. 93 of the madras hindu religious and charitable endowments act, 1951, was a bar to maintainability of the suit.

tagline: Ammathayee Ammal & Anr vs Kumaresan & Others on 15 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: kumaresan was a man of considerable property. he married four times. the second and fourth wives of r contested the suit. the trial court also decided against the two step - mothers who thereupon appealed to the court. the case was first brought to the supreme court in 2009.

tagline: Biswabahan Das vs Gopen Chandra Hazarika & Ors on 21 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: the respondent was challenged before the board of revenue in an appeal by the appellant. he had compounded an offence of illegally felling green trees by paying com - pensation. the board was right in considering the responseent's conduct in rendering compensation for forest offence and suitability.

tagline: Union Of India vs The Metal Corporation Of India ... on 5 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: metal corporation of india ( acquisition of undertaking ) act, 1965, was enacted for acquiring in the public interest. act was to vest in the central government on the commencement of the act. the act contravened art. 31 ( 2 ) of the constitution and was therefore voided.

tagline: K.P. Raghavan And Anr. vs M.H. Abbas And Anr. on 6 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: a complaint was filed against two appellants, of whom appellant no. 1. the complainant had cultivation of water melons in a field to the west of his house near a railway line. the complaint was bled on the allegation that complainant was cultivation jointly with one seedi.

tagline: State Of Madhya Pradesh vs Kaluram on 5 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: the state of madhya pradesh took proceedings to recover from k - as arrears of land revenue. one k stood surety for j along with surety. j was declared the highest bidder. the amount of the bid was payable in four installments. it includes rights which the creditor has against the property at the date of the contract.

tagline: State Of Uttar Pradesh vs Raja Anand Brahma Shah on 16 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: state of uttar pradesh issued two notifications in 1953, by one of which the uttar pradesh zamindari abolition and land reforms act, 1950, was amended by u. p. act 14 of 1958, and while appeals were pending in the high court, the definition in s. 3 ( 8 ) was amended. the act of 1964, by which the repellant - state contended that the pargana was an " estate " either within art. 3 of the act.

tagline: C.P. Sarathy Mudaliar vs Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... on 21 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: the assessee is a hindu undivided family of which the manager is sarathy. in the assessment years 1955 - 56 and 1956 - 57, the family was sought to be charged to tax in respect of sums of rs. 5, 790 and rs. 39, 085 advanced as loans on the footing that they represented divided income fell within section 2 of the income - tax act.

tagline: Messrs. Associated Clothiers Ltd vs Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... on 23 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: the appellant company was originally registered as / s. phelps & co. ltd. but on march 21, 1952 by an order under s. 11 ( 4 ) of the indian companies act, 1913, its name was changed to " messrs associated clothiers ltd " the original cost of the building was rs. 97, 252 / - and its written value was shown as its 2, 4, 573 /. in the balance sheet far the account year ending march 31, 1953.

tagline: State Of Assam vs Horizon Union & Anr on 23 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: bachawat, r. s. dayal, raghubar rao, m. sikri and m. m. were benchmarked for an industrial tribunal on the ground that he was not an additional district judge for three years as required by s. 7a ( 3 ) ( aa ) of the industrial disputes act.

tagline: P.L. Lakhanpal vs Union Of India & Ors on 21 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: petitioner who was editor of a newspaper was detained by and order of the central government under r. 3oa ( 9 ) the petitioner challenged the second order for the following grounds of his original detention. the order continued the detention set out only the defence of india and civil defence. the first order directed the petitioners'detention with a view to preventing him from acting in any manner prejudicial.

tagline: State Of Gujarat vs M/S. Kailash Engineering Co on 26 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: the respondent company obtained a contract from the western railway administration for construction of third class coaches. under the contract he constructed three coaches and submitted a bill which was properly certified on october 4, 1958. after the bill had been paid, the additional collector held however the transaction was a sale on which tax was paid.

tagline: Gulabhai Vallabhbhai Desai Etc vs Union Of India & Ors on 27 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: five petitioners challenged validity of regulation under arts 14, 19 and 31 of the constitution, while union of india contended that regulation was protected by art. 31 - a ( 2 ) ) does not lend its protection to their expropriation. the regulation must come within the compendious definition of " estate " under art.

tagline: Jamuna Singh vs State Of Bihar on 22 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: the appellant was convicted of abetting the offence under s. 436. but maintained the conviction of the. appellant for the offence read with s. 109 of the indian penal code for having instigated one of his co - accused to burn a hut. the high court acquitted the co - defendant of the offence.

tagline: Srichand K. Khetwani vs State Of Maharashtra on 27 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: indian evidence act, ss. 45 and 114 specimen writing of accused obtained but not sent to hand - writing expert - court. appellant was tried and convicted along with others and was convicted by the high court. the appellant and others were convicted of conspiracy - licences.

tagline: State Of Assam Etc vs Kripanath Sarma & Ors. Etc on 23 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: the respondents were elementary school teachers appointed under the assam basic education act. the act was repealed by the a, % am elementary education act, 1962, which came into force on 5th october 1962. under the 1962 - act a state board was to be constituted, and in the place of the school boards functioning under the 1954 - act would be taken over by the state board.

tagline: Krishnamurthy @ Tailor Krishnan vs Public Prosecutor, Madras on 26 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: the appellant was charged under s. 3 ( 1 ) of the act as his previous conviction was under the madras suppression of immoral traffic act, 1930. the house was used for such purposes, undoubtedly for the gain of the money for committing prostitution. appellant's conviction could not be considered to be a second conviction under the act.

tagline: Sukh Lal And Ors vs State Bank Of India And Ors on 13 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: state bank of india and ors had advanced loans to the business. they applied to the tribunal set up under the displaced persons act, 1951 and the bank's suit was'also transferred to a tribunal. the words of the defi - nition in s. 2 ( 10 ) read with s. 3 ( 6 ) are sufficiently wide to include the law of a person who had residence in india as a place of residence in an area now forming part of pakistan.

tagline: T.D. Kumar And Brothers (P.) Ltd. vs Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... on 14 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: the entire share capital of the company was held by three persons who may be called " kumars " between september 19 to november 14, 1952. the entire sharing capital was held in by two out of the five ghoshes. the income tax officer disallowed the claim and the order was confirmed by the appellate assistant commissioner.

tagline: Har Swarup & Another vs Brij Bhushan Saran & Others on 14 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: a petition filed by two electors seeking to set aside his election on the ground inter alia that a corrupt practice was committed during the election in that r, after he had with, drawn his candidature. an appeal to the high court was dismissed and an appeal was dismissed.

tagline: Prafulla Kumar Malik vs Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... on 15 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: high court of orissa under section 66a ( 2 ) of the indian income tax act, 1922. the appellant was required to supply paddy and rice of a certain standard quality " known as " fair average quality " under the agreement, the quality of foodgrains must conform to the'fair average'standard quality.

tagline: Rajaanand Brahma Shah vs State Of Uttar Pradesh & Ors on 16 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: rajaanand brahma shah's application of land acquisition act was challenged by a writ petition. in 1950, the state government issued a notification under s. 4 ( 1 ) of the act, 1894 stating that the appellant's land was needed for the public purpose of limestone quarrying. it was also notified that the case was one of urgency and that the application was not for _ a public purpose.

tagline: Wazirchand Mahajan And Anr vs Union Of India on 12 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: the appellant purchased from the himachal pradesh government the right to extract and collect certain medicinal herbs from the forests of chamba district. the period of agreement was one year from september 1, 1960. under an arbitration clause in the agreement all disputes between the parties were to be referred to the deputy commissioner, mandi district.

tagline: State Of Mysore vs Guduthur Thimmappa & Son, & Anr on 30 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: madras general sales - tax ( turnover and assessment ) rules, 1939 applied. non - resident buyers never entered the state either for entering into contracts for the sale or for taking delivery. the buyers were not the last dealers not exempt from taxation and was accepted by the high court. in appeal the appellant - state contended that a buyer who was not resident within the area of the act could not be held to be the last dealer.

tagline: Samyukta Socialist Party vs Election Commission Of India & Anr on 30 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: in 1962 the praja socialist party had the'hut'as its election symbol. in 1965 the socialist party and socialist party merged to form the samyukta socialist party. but the election commission was challenged in a writ petition before the high court and the writ was refused an appeal.

tagline: Lachhi Ram vs State Of Punjab on 2 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: lachhi ram has come up to court in this appeal by special leave against the high court of punjab upholding the conviction and sentence of life for life. the appellant and his brother chet ram visited devi ram in his village tigaon and made a demand in respect of the property, adding a threat that otherwise he would have to pay heavily.

tagline: State Of Uttar Pradesh vs Yashpal Singh on 30 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: judgment bhargava, j. 1, was an agriculturist in agra. the respondent had shown a gross receipt of rs. 10, 899 as the proceeds of sale of all his agricultural produce. the assessment board expressed its opinion on it and referred the following question.

tagline: Cherumanalil Lakshmi And Ors vs Mulivil Kunninamkandy Narayani ... on 12 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: the transactions were styled kanam - kuzhikanam transactions. they were entitled to enjoy the lands with the standing trees, plant other fruit - bearing trees thereon. documents did not contain any recital that they created security for repayment of a debt nor purported to be transactions for securing debts such as a mortgage.

tagline: Swadeshi Cotton Mills Co. Ltd. vs Commissioner Of Income-Tax, U. P. ... on 20 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: judgment bhargava j. - the appellant is a public limited company carrying on the business manufacturing and selling cloth and other textile goods. appellant had to pay a sum of rs. 15, 000 as compensation to one of the contracting parties and rs. 20, 000 to the other contracting parties who demanded compensation for breach of contract.

tagline: Chhi Ram vs State Of Punjab on 2 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: the appellant was convicted of murder by the sessions judge mainly on the evidence of the approver's evidence related to earlier incident. the high court did not consider it safe to rely on a part of the approval of the approved approvalr ’ s evidence which related to an earlier incident but found that his main story was reliable and reliable.

tagline: Commissioner Of Income-Tax, U.P vs Nainital Bank Ltd on 15 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: nainital bank settled claims of constituents by crediting the value of jewellery. jewellery pledged with bank stolen - bank crediting cost of jewellery to constituents. but high court in reference under s. 66 ( 2 ) of the indian lncome - tax act, 1922 allowed it.

tagline: Swadeshi Cotton Mills Co. Ltd. vs Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... on 20 September, 1966
summarized_judgment: appellant entered into two contracts with two other parties for purchase of textile machinery in order to expand its factory. appellant had to pay a sum of rs. 15, 000 as compensation to one of the contracting parties and rs. 20, 000 to the other contracting parties who demanded compensation for breach of contract.

tagline: Kantamani Venkata Narayana & Sons vs First Additional Income-Tax ... on 27 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: the income - tax officer filed writ petitions in the high court, in reply to which he filed affidavits stating that he had reason to believe that the assessee had not disclosed fully and truly all material facts. the writ petitions were rejected and the order was confirmed in appeal.

tagline: State Of Madras vs Madurai Mills Co., Ltd on 4 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: the respondent submitted a revised assessment order as per the order of the commercial tax officer who was the assessing authority. on 28th november 1952, the respondingent presented a revision petition before the deputy commissioner of commercial taxes raising the only objection. the board of revenue issued a notice to respondent stating that it proposed revise the assessment by including in the net turnover a sum representing the value of cotton purchased by outside the state.

tagline: Bihta Co-Operative Development ... vs The Bank Of Bihar & Ors on 12 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: the first plaintiff was a society registered under the bihar and orissa co - operative societies act, 1935. the society had an account with the first defendant bank, and the second plaintiff was its secretary. a sum of rs. 11, 000 was withdrawn from the account by means of a cheque which did not come out of the cheque book of the society but surrendered by an ex - constituent.

tagline: Chandradhar Goswami & Ors vs The Gauhati Bank Ltd on 14 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: the appellants through their karta had an open mutual and current account with the respondent bank. they borrowed from the bank and also paid monies into it. the court granted the suit and the high court upheld the order of a further sum of rs. 10, 000 was advanced to an appellant in favour of the bank. under that deedfurther amounts up to a limit of rs 16, 000 could be advanced.

tagline: The Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... vs Sri Meenakshi Mills Ltd. & Ors on 25 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: the assessee - companies carried on business in madurai and each had a branch at pudukottai. they hold majority share in a bank which, too, had its head office at madurai. t, who was a shareholder of the bank, was the moving figure in the assessees - companies.

tagline: George Da Costa vs Controller Of Estate Duty In ... on 28 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: the appellant's father purchased a house in the joint names of himself and his wife. in 1954 the parents made a gift of the said property to their two sons - - residence - based only on filial affection - - for the purpose of the duty or not. the father died in 1959, more than four years after the gift.

tagline: Commissioner Of Income-Tax, West ... vs East Coast Commercial Co. Ltd on 11 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: members of family held 4, 015 shares, out of 4, 391 shares in the respondent company, which was a public limited company. a majority of the shares were held benami. an offer of settlement was made in respect of the " secreted income " treating them as an association of persons.

tagline: Joint Family Of Udayan Chinubhai ... vs Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... on 14 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: indian income tax act ( 11 of 1922 ), s. 25a and s. 34 - order recording partition of hindu undivided family - - power to reassess family as unit afterwards - - as a unit afterwards. in 1952, the income - tax officer granted the application and for the period after the high court's decree assessed all the members of the family separately.

tagline: Rm. Ar., Ar. Rm. Ar. Ramanathan ... vs Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... on 27 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: the supreme court of ceylon ordered the refund of the estate duty with legal interest thereon. in the case, the assessee took one third share of the area. the administrative panel of the justices ruled that the court had to refund estate duty. the court ruled on appeal that estate duty should have been refunded.

tagline: The Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... vs Smt. Kasturbai Walchand Trust, ... on 31 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: in 1946, the respondent executed a deed of surrender whereby she gave up her beneficial interest in the trust. in the course of assessment to income tax in respect of the income from the trust properties for the assessment years 1956 - 57 to 1959 - 60. appellate assistant commissioner, on appeal held that the income was exempt under s. 4 ( 3 ) ( i ) of the trust deed.

tagline: Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... vs Prithvi Insurance Co. Ltd on 26 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: indian income tax act, madras vs. respondent, carried on business of life and general insurance. but appellate assistant commissioner and the tribunal confirmed the view of the income - tax officer. the court ruled that two lines of business may be considered as the " same business " or different business. the test suggested on behalf of the revenue could not be accepted.

tagline: State Of Assam & Ors vs Shri Kanak Chandra Dutta on 3 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: the respondent was dismissed without complying with the provisions of art 311 ( 2 ) of the constitution. a mauzadar is a servant and the holder of a civil post, under the state of assam and was entitled to the protection of the article. india's right to select and appoint holder of the post, its right to suspend and dismiss him.

tagline: O. Rm. M. Sp. Sv. Firm vs The Commissioner Of ... on 14 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: entire foreign income of business abroad remitted to india whether tax under s. 3 of the 1918 act, was on income tax act, 1918. the firm was dissolved on march 2, 1952, and its members continued the business as partners in the assessee firm. the high court disagreed with the appellate assistant commissioner and held - in favour of the department.

tagline: Miss Dhun Dadabhoy Kapadia vs Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... on 31 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: assessee renounced her right to take the new shares by, sale in the open market and realised a sum of rs. 45, 262. 50 was correct when the value of the old share fell to rs. 253. 75as a result of the loss of about rs. 38, 000.

tagline: Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... vs The Canara Bank Ltd on 13 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: the respondent bank had its head office at mangalore. it also opened a branch at karachi in 1946. it was agreed that a hundred pakistani rupees were equivalent to a hundred and forty - four indian rupeees. the commissioner of income tax appealed to the high court.

tagline: Hindustan Antibiotics Ltd vs The Workmen & Ors on 3 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: india's government made a reference under s. 10 ( 1 ) of the industrial disputes act, 1947 for adjudication. indian companies act gave its award in two parts and gave, inter alia, the following findings rejecting the contention of the company that in fixing the wage scale, the company was in effect financed and controlled by the government.

tagline: Ashwin Nanubhai Vyas vs State Of Maharashtra & Anr on 10 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: the complainant died after the complaint had been field under s. 198 cr. p. c. the application for substitution of the complaint was resisted by the accused - appllant, on the ground that only the aggreived person could be the complaint and on the complaint's death.

tagline: Commissioner Of Income-Tax, West ... vs Juggilal Kamalapat on 7 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: a new partnership firm was constituted between j. and the trust by means of a partnership deed which specified the shares of the two partners in profits and losses. the three brothers created a trust, with themselves as the first three trustees. they executed an unregistered deed of relinquishment by which they relinquished their rights in and claims to all the properties and assets of the firm.

tagline: Chandra Mohini Srivastava vs Avinash Prasad Srivastava & Anr on 13 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: chandra mohini srivastava and anr filed a suit against his wife, the appellant, for dissolution of his marriage with her on the ground that she was living in adultery. in appeal, the high court held that the wife was not. in 2008, the respondent applied for revocation of the grant of special leave to appeal to this court.

tagline: Lala Hari Chand Sarda vs Mizo District Council & Anr on 28 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: the appellant filed a writ petition, claiming the order was mala fide in the sense that the number of non - tribal traders reached the maximum. the order and s. 3 of lushai hills district council and anr were granted licences to new traders. the high court maintained the order. in appeal to this court.

tagline: Hindustan Construction Company ... vs Union Of India on 12 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: appellant entered into contract with india for construction of railway bridges. the appellant filed an application under s. 14 of the indian arbitration act 1940. it was objected by the court and appellants application for passing - a judgment in terms of the award was dismissed. a revision petition before the high court failed to reach court.

tagline: Babu Manmohan Das Shah & Ors vs Bishun Das on 12 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: appellant filed a suit for the latter's ejection under section 3 of the u. p. ( 1 / 2 ft ) appellant claimed that the respondent carried out material alterations. appellant was entitled to eviction on proof of material alterations - - or whether proof was necessary of diminished value of property - - and if proof is necessary. the appellant is the owner of two shops rented to the respondingent.

tagline: Standard Mills Co. Ltd vs Commissioner Of Wealth-Tax, ... on 6 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: in the larkin of the wealth tax act 1957, two deductions claimed the company : ( i ) the amount of estimated income tax for the assessment year and ( ii ) ( m ) of the act. excess of the aggregate value of the assets over the debts is the net wealth of the assessee on valuation date, s. 7 has not operation. it was contingent upon the determination of employment by death, incapacity, retirement or resignation of employee.

tagline: Chandulal Harjivandas, Jamnagar vs Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... on 14 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: in 1959, the life insurance corporation of india was liable to pay the sum assured a minor - proposer of insurance his father payment of premium out of taxable income of assured - - if entitled to rebate of income - tax. in the absence of such adoption it was the proposer who would be entitled to the amounts payable by the corporation, and not the assessee.

tagline: Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... vs Godavari Sugar Mills Ltd on 10 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: order under s. 23a was declared a dividend of rs. 3, 68, 433 for its accounting year ended may 31, 1948. in the course of its assessment to income - tax for the assessment year 1949, it ceased to apply within 6 months of meeting not aplicable to asessee company. the high court decided the question in favour of the respondent company.

tagline: Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... vs A. Tellery And Sons Pvt. Ltd. on 4 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: allahabad woollen mills supplied yarn to the respondent for three years ending march 31, 1947, march 31 1947, and 1949 - 50. the act was used to obtain yarn from allahabad for the purpose of its business, viz., the manufacture and export of carpets at allahabad.

tagline: S.A.L. Narayana Row, ... vs Model Mills Nagpur Ltd. on 6 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: judgment shah, j. 1, calculated the respondent - company's total income for the assessment year 1952 - 53 at rs. 23, 596. the order dated the 27th july, 1955, and brought that amount to tax. order was complied with by india's commissioner of income - tax and order was quashed.

tagline: Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... vs K.Y. Pilliah And Sons on 13 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: the income - tax officer found that in the business of purchasing cloth carried on by the assessee. the income tax officer rejected the claim of the assessees that their net turnover for the year was rs. 7, 000 in the name of one sampangappa, the son of k. y. pilliah.

tagline: Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... vs Kantilal Nathuchand Sami on 11 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: indian income tax, 1922, was registered under s. 26a of the indian income - tax act. 1922, for the assessment years 1958 - 59, 195960 and 1960 - 61. the firm suffered loss in speculation business for two years - such loss whether to be apportioned between partners or to be carried forward and set off against profit in the subsequent year.

tagline: Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... vs Bidhu Bhushan Sarkar (Dead) ... on 3 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: an earlier notice under s. 34 of the income - tax act 1922 passed an order to the effect that the income should be taken in the assessment on a second return for the same year before the principal officer. the appellate assistant commissioner therefore set aside an assessment order, but an appeals court reversed this decision.

tagline: Parekh Wadilal Jivanbhai vs Commissioner Of Income-Tax, M. P. ... on 28 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: three partners applied to the income - tax officer for registration of the firm under s. 26a of the act, 1922 and registration was granted. but for the assessment year 1953 - 54, the profits have been apportioned equally. in all applications for registration, the three partners were shown to have shared profits equally.

tagline: Income-Tax Officer, Alleppey vs S. Veeriah Reddiar on 10 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: a notice was issued by the appellant under section 34 of the income tax act. it challenged the validity of that notice by a petition under article 226 of the constitution before the kerala high court. the facts and grounds were given in an affidavit in support of the petition.

tagline: Commissioner Of Taxes Assam, ... vs Prabhat Marketing Co. Ltd., ... on 27 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: the respondent was a registered dealer under the assam sales tax act, 1947. appeals to assistant commissioner of taxes failed as also second ap - peals to the assam board of revenue. high court held that value of containers was not assessable to sales tax unless separate price was charged for the containers.

tagline: Commissioner Of Agricultural ... vs New Ambadi Estates Ltd. on 12 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: the respondent is a company which, for assessment to agricultural income - tax, for the assessment year 1952 - 53, filed a return showing a loss of rs. 43, 071. the response to which the account books were produced, was produced. the respondingent applied to the commissioner of agricultural income tax asking for a reference of the following question.

tagline: Bihar Mines Ltd vs Union Of India on 3 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: land reforms act, 1950 and 1986, provided that mining leases subsisted immediately before the date of vesting were deemed to be leases by the state of bihar. the lease was for the mining of soap stone, kaoline etc. in 1933, and 1954, the mines and minerals ( regulation and development ) act were the last in favour of appellants.

tagline: Gujarat Pottery Works vs B. P. Sood, Controller Of Mining ... on 3 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: the lease was executed in 1951, in execution of a decree for specific performance. lease was not for the purpose of merely winning the mineral but was also for extracting the mineral and taking it away ; therefore, protection of art. the lease in favour of the appellant was dated 1951, but was not available to save the reduction in the lease without paying compensation.

tagline: M/S. Bharat Barrel & Drum Mfg. Co vs L. K. Bose & Ors on 5 October, 1966
summarized_judgment: the appellant company carried on the business of manufacturing barrels and for that purpose required steel sheets. by'reason of the essential commodities act, 1955 the iron and steel ( conirol ) order, 1956 and diverse orders passed by the controller. appellant claimed that it had already - paid rs. 7 lacs and odd to the 6th respondent in respect of earlier release orders.

tagline: Soni Lalji Jetha & Ors vs Soni Kalidas Devchand & Ors on 14 October, 1966
